results.notes:
Growing on a grassy patch under the canopy of a massive scarlet oak. These little boletes fruit there a few times every year and are usually the first boletes of the season. This year they appeared earlier than usual following a wet and warmer-than-average spring. I usually don’t pick them. What’s the point?!
It rained heavily the night before, so surprisingly the fb was not in such a terrible shape. The bottom half of the stipe, however, was thoroughly rotten and damaged by fly larvae inside.
It dropped a few spores, but I understand that campestris, harrisonii and rubellus all have almost identically sized spores (as per M. Kuo).
I don’t think this is rubellus just because it’s supposed to be an exotic imported species. The chemical tests are very consistent with those reported by M. Kuo for harrisonii: KOH = dingy mustard yellow on cap cuticle and orange on cap flesh; NH4OH = initially negative, then slowly pale yellow on cap cuticle, negative on cap flesh but erased the bluing.

On smooth bark of younger coast live oak (Quercus agrifolia) trunk, about a mile from the ocean above El Capitan State Park.

Thallus light grey, rimose crust, K+Y. Apothecia are pale, from greyish to light peachy orange, always plane, with a persistent raised white thalline margin that is K+Y. Epihymenium is dark brown with small POL+ yellowish crystals soluble in K. Amphithecium with a pocket of large POL+ crystals that are not soluble in K. Amphithecial cortex present.

Spores 8/ascus, simple, hyaline, broadly ellipsoid. About 13.5×8¬µm.

results.notes:
On smooth bark of younger coast live oak (Quercus agrifolia) trunk, about a mile from the ocean above El Capitan State Park.

Thallus an indeterminate areolate crust, greenish, matte, thin, without soredia or blastidia. Apothecia common, beginning plane with thick thalline margin concolorous with thallus, becoming convex with a reduced margin. Disk black, epruinose. Epihymenium dark brown, POL-. Hymenium hyaline, IKI+blue persistent, paraphyses simple, not very conglutinated. Hypothecium hyaline.

Spores 1-septate, becoming brown, bean shaped, with apical and septal swellings (Physcia type) with a light torus. Septa becoming slightly swollen in KOH. Spores mounted in Lugol’s and heat treated (see photos): Average size 14.3×7.7 (n=20).

I first put this at either Rinodina laevigata or Rinodina santae-monicae. Septal swelling doesn’t seem sufficient to push these into Dirinia-type spores for santae-monicae. But the spores seemed too small so I measured 20 and the average is way too small for either of these species. I’m looking at Rinodina freyi now but haven’t made a final determination.

results.notes:
I’d like to point out something VERY important about this observation. Now Ganoderma tsugae seems to exclusively parasitize the Eastern Hemlock which is being wiped out along the East Coast due to the Hemlock Woolly Adelgid an invasive insect. I have visited this area around this time in 2013, 2017, and now 2018. In 2013 there were a few samples of G. tsugae found in this forest that was so heavily canopied that in full sun most of my surroundings were in dark shade. In 2017 the forest was heavily ‘thinned’. Most trees had barely any needles, but G. tsugae was so abundant I couldn’t carry all the samples I found if I had a backpack (not that I’d take that many if I could). Clearly the Adelgid had devastated this area. This year almost none of the trees had needles at all and most of them had lost their branches as well with plenty of trees toppled over. I also found almost NO G. tsugae samples.

It’s clear that in a healthy forest only a few dying trees could host G. tsugae and as the Adelgid drastically weakened the trees G. tsugae began to claim lots of them, but now that they’re almost all gone there’s nowhere left for G. tsugae to parasitize. I suspect next year I will find none.

results.notes:
Baorangia bicolor complex.

This mushroom [one of what I am convinced are several different species] is commonly identified as Baorangia bicolor in Western Pennsylvania. It grows under oak (a recent find was made by someone else under birch) and has a number of consistent characteristics.

STIPE: It always has a pillar stipe that is even from bottom to top. The skin of the stipe is red with yellow streaks but no reticulation. The context within the stipe is yellow with red larval tunnels. It does not stain. Mycelium is white.

CAP: The cap starts out the same deep red as the stipe and distinctly rounded. It flattens with age and loses its red color, gradually becoming a nondescript tan with echoes of red in certain spots. The context of the cap can vary from pale yellow to white and does not bruise blue with the possible exception of a faint tint‚Ä¶ but that could also be contamination from the pores in older specimens.

PORES: The pores start out as a clean, bright yellow that does not bruise at all. The specimen in these photos was also marked with ‚ÄúSPP‚Äù but you cannot see it because there was no reaction. The pores slowly darken toward a deeper yellow with age and always gain an array of reddish dots. Older specimens have pores that slowly (5-20 seconds) bruise a grayish blue. That blue resolves to an almost black shade over the course of perhaps 30 minutes, which then fades even more slowly to the brown seen in later photos.

SUBJECTIVE: This is not a particularly desirable bolete even in its youth. It has a typical bolete aroma and a mild flavor, but it lacks the density that characterizes other genera even though it has a relatively thin tube layer. There is nothing ‚Äúbad‚Äù about it, but also nothing that would make it an eager target. In a similar way it is vulnerable to bugs but in a middling way. It rarely appears in a thoroughly chewed format, but is equally rarely found totally clean.

MEASUREMENTS: The largest specimens push 6‚Äù in diameter and perhaps 3-4‚Äù in height. There were two specimens measured for this observation. The older one was 3‚Äù in cap diameter, with a cap that was 3/4‚Äù thick. The thickest part of the tube layer was a bit less than 3/8‚Äù. The smaller specimen had a cap 1-1/2‚Äù in diameter and pores that were no more than 1/32‚Äù deep.

CHEMICAL TESTS ON THE MATURE SPECIMEN:

Cap Skin w/Ammonia: No reaction
Cap Skin w/KOH: Might have darkened, but no clear reaction
Cap Skin w/FeSO4: Olive

Cap Context w/Ammonia: No reaction
Cap Context w/KOH: Orange/pink
Cap Context w/FeSO4: Olive

Pores w/Ammonia: No reaction
Pores w/KOH: Red/brown
Pores w/FeSO4: Olive

CHEMICAL TESTS ON THE BABY:

Cap Skin w/Ammonia: Orange
Cap Skin w/KOH: Faded to the tan seen in age
Cap Skin w/FeSO4: Olive

Cap Context w/Ammonia: No reaction
Cap Context w/KOH: Orange/pink
Cap Context w/FeSO4: Olive

Pores w/Ammonia: Light brown
Pores w/KOH: None/pale orange
Pores w/FeSO4: Olive

  • All chemicals were applied using a soaked Q-tip

results.notes: Growing on grass/soil near near both hardwoods, and pine (more prolific growth near the former, oak precisely). Cap was slightly viscid when wet. Flesh firm, kind of having blue-ish, buff/grey tones, sometimes even bluish tones throughout. Slightly tan/brown on disc upon age. Gills emarginate/sinuate. Some in small clusters of two or three. Stipe is fibrillose, generally equal with younger specimens distributing a tapering towards bottom. Some of the older specimens have a slightly enlarged base; sometimes tapering beneath swollen base. No noticeable bruising, though some slightly brownish bruising towards base of stipe. Spore deposit white. Found in same area as Obs 371578 and likely the same species.

results.notes:
A few fruiting bodies growing in grass/lawn under a large basswood/linden (Tilia sp.), with a flowering cherry tree nearby. These are the only trees that are planted in a row on this island between a highway and service road. The photographed fruiting bodies were plucked out by squirrels or landscapers earlier today or a day ago, so they are not in best shape.
The caps are concave to funnel-shape, up to 7 cm wide (wider if caps made flat). The cuticle is violaceus-purple to bluish-lavender with a hint of bluish-gray and perhaps brownish-gray hues in the gathering twilight/around sunset time, showing some creamy-yellow tones in the center; the disc is covered with a distinct and dense layer of concolorous granules/crusts that can be seen without a lens, giving the surface a ‘cloudy’ appearance; the cap margin in tuberculate-striate; the cuticle peels between 1/2 and 2/3 of radius. The gills are whitish to pale creamy, forking only at juncture with stipe, fairly crowded; the darker reflection between gills blades suggest cream to ochre spore print. The stipe is whitish or maybe with a slight hint of brownish-lavender flush. The odor is nill or maybe slightly of bread/dough (due to age/decay?). The taste of flesh is mild or maybe slightly and transiently acrid.
After consulting Kibby & Fatto (1993), I came up with the following suspects with more or less matching cap colors and other pertinent properties: azurea, brunneoviolacea, grisea, ornaticeps, and parazurea. According to Lime-trees and Basswoods: A Biological Monograph of the Genus Tilia, grisea and parazurea have been documented growing under basswood in Europe.
I was hoping that the combination of the cap color, granulose deposits on the disc and the association with basswood would be enough to ID this mushroom.

Scattered in troops amongst pine needle litter within mixed (predominantly pine) woods. Odor milder in younger specimens; strong in age; sweet, slightly rancid almost in older samples. Cap not dry, buff, slightly gritty to the touch. Cap is flat, slightly depressed with margins inrolled on some specimens. Cap also displaying defined umbo on some specimens, especially younger ones. Fruiting bodies are generally same color throughout, gills and stipe maybe a shade or two lighter than cap. Stipe covered in a fine powder like texture. Also, gills having more of a yellow tint upon maturity. Gills attached to decurrent, latex whitish-clear, slowing becoming more water-like. No noticeable bruising/drying of latex. Deposit cream, slightly yellow.

results.notes: Scattered solitarily beneath pine in needle liter. Small, cap about 1-3 cm wide and fruiting body about 3-6 cm tall. Stipe about 0.5 to 1.5 cm wide, color similar to cap though white near base. Latex not really present at first, though slightly visible within minutes. Mostly clear/white color, not changing in time.

results.notes: Growing in pine needle liter. Scattered in groups of 3 or 4. Cap white with slight yellow/gold hues in the center. Appearance slightly viscid in younger specimens or when wet; though dry to the touch. Very light, if at all, remnants of universal veil on cap. Convex, becoming flat and sometimes concave in age. Margin slightly striate, especially in older specimens. Gills close, free. Some forking (not frequent) with many short lamellae present, white becoming pale/dingy yellowish/tan in age. Stipe about 1-2 cm wide, small ring slightly above midpoint of stipe. Stipe bruising light brown in age and after damaging, very slowly if any. Abrupt bulb at base of stipe, relatively spherical with collar. Old mild. Spore deposit white. 8.5-10 × 5-8; broadly elliptical.

results.notes:
Habitat: Under pines and a few hardwoods in a grassy area in a public park in NW Georgia (Floyd County), US.

Pileus: Ranges from yellow to pink. Particularly pink around the margin. Iron salts: Negative reaction. KOH: Olive brown with yellow hints. Ammonia: Subtle darkening. Not much of a reaction. DNS.

Flesh: Dark pink with a little bit of gold throughout. DNS. Iron Salts: Darkens the already present pink. KOH: yellow-olive. Ammonia: Not much of a reaction. Maybe slightly gray tones.

Pores: Pale gold. Staining slightly blue with touch or cut (immediate). Iron salts: Negative. KOH: Dark yellow to pale orange. Ammonia: slowly changes to deep olive.

Stipe: Golden with pink towards apex and yellow towards base. Striations increase towards apex.

Flavor: Pleasant.

This is really throwing me off. The closest I could get was Harrya chromapes, but I am reading that it is nonstaining? Is it more likely this is Aureoboletus?

results.notes:
Pileus: 8-8.5 cm in diameter; light gray-brown when young and lighter toward the margin, darkening with maturity, convex to planoconvex, smooth when young becoming dry, shiny, and wrinkled with age, striated, striations one-third to one-half the radius, nonappendiculate; volva present as white, floccose warts or patches

Stipe: 4.5-6.5 × 1-1.5 cm wide; white, floccose when young, changing to a very light tan color with handling in the older specimen, tapering upward and flaring slightly at the apex, terminating at the base in a turnip shape, flesh white, unchanging, hollowing somewhat; annulus concolorous with stipe, persistent, collapsing mid-stipe; volva present as friable white collar above the turnip-shaped base, some remnants left behind after excavation

Lamellae: free, white, crowded, appearing cream-colored en masse

Odor/Taste: Not distinct; taste not recorded

Habitat: Under very mature Quercus alba with a singular Cornus florida close by. Should be noted that the dogwood was closer to the specimens than the White Oak.

results.notes:
Buttons starting out a light gray, then gray-brown and then straw-colored to pale ochre-buff. Always pretty light, though the strong sun may make it appear a bit paler in the picture. Pruinose silky white bloom evident on cap fibers and a (pruinose?) thin white margin, eventually coming off revealing more light-brown area. Smell weak. Near the base of a log in mixed conifer forest. Stipe thick for the size of the cap, shiny and white, with appressed pale fibrils, swollen toward the base (more or less club-shaped) with tiny white fuzzy hairs at base (see picture).
Spores a medium dark brown, rounded, 9-11 × 4.5-6.5

results.notes: Growing in damp soil beneath oak, scattered. Cap dry, slightly damp/not viscid. Concave, becoming slightly upturned/convex in age. Grey, slight hues of lilac, yellow/olivaceous around disc. Cap cracking on surface into smaller, irregular grayish patches towards margin. Gills annexed to slightly sinuate, whiteish at first, becoming cream/pale yellow in age. Some forking present near margin. Stipe chalk white and smooth, becoming crumbly in age. Base of stipe tapered and becoming yellowish in age. Odor mild. Spore deposit white/cream.

results.notes: Growing scattered and sometimes in small clusters of 2 or 3, sometimes barely emerging from soil. Underneath oak, in damp soil/moss. Cap dry, dingy and spotted, straw yellow. Color slightly lighter than pileus, fringed near margin with a few shorter lamellae present. Stipe white becoming yellowish/brown, tapered towards base. Odor mild. Taste very acrid/hot. Spore deposit white/cream.

results.notes:
On Juniperus californicus along Santa Barbara Canyon Road, southeast of Cuyama Valley.

Thallus indeterminate, light gray, dull, scarcely present. Apothecia adnate, dark brown black, dull, epruinose, quickly convex with a persistent but thin thalline margin. Epihymenium red brown, POL-. Hymenium and hypothecium hyaline, the latter slightly dirty. Paraphyses not conglutinated, branched at tip, with a dark apical cap.

Spores Type A development with young spores showing no apical swelling. 1-septate, brown, ellipsoid, often bean-shaped to somewhat attenuated, Physconia type. Initially with an apical swelling and angular lumina, but lumina becoming round then filling the space so mature spores have no or very little apical swelling. In K the setpa swell slightly, septal thickening minimal. Average size 14.0×6.6¬µm (n=13)
results.location_name: Santa Barbara Co., California, USA
